claim: The majority of a set of numbers cannot be larger than the average.

supporting.text: By definition, the average (mean) of a set of numbers is the sum of the numbers divided by the count of numbers, so at least half the numbers must be less than or equal to the average.

attacks.text: By definition, the average (mean) of a set of numbers is the sum of the numbers divided by the count of numbers, so at least half the numbers must be less than or equal to the average.
This assumes the distribution is symmetric or left-skewed; in a right-skewed distribution, the majority can be above the mean.
Right-skewed distributions are less common in real-world datasets compared to symmetric or left-skewed ones, so the original argument holds in most cases.
The median is a better measure than the mean for skewed distributions, where the majority can indeed be above the mean.
The claim specifically refers to the average (mean), not the median, so this counter-argument is irrelevant to the original statement.

attacks.text: If the majority of numbers were larger than the average, their excess would require an impossible balancing by the minority being smaller than the average.

supporting.text: The median, which is the middle value in an ordered set, is always less than or equal to the average in a positively skewed distribution, reinforcing that the majority cannot exceed the average.

attacks.text: The median, which is the middle value in an ordered set, is always less than or equal to the average in a positively skewed distribution, reinforcing that the majority cannot exceed the average.
In a negatively skewed distribution, the median is greater than the average, which contradicts the claim that the majority cannot exceed the average.

The claim refers to 'the majority,' not just the median. Even in positively skewed distributions, more than half the data can lie above the average if the tail is long enough.
For the majority to exceed the average, the tail must be extremely long and thin, which is rare in practice and often negligible in statistical analysis.

supporting.text: Statistical principles confirm that in any finite set of real numbers, the majority cannot be strictly greater than the arithmetic mean without violating the definition of the mean.

attacks.text: Statistical principles confirm that in any finite set of real numbers, the majority cannot be strictly greater than the arithmetic mean without violating the definition of the mean.
